title: Greta Thunberg to climate-focused UN: ‘You have stolen my childhood... with empty words’
text:
‘This is all wrong. I shouldn’t be up here. I should be in school on the other side of the ocean. Yet you come to us young people for hope. How dare you. You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words.’

That’s 16-year-old Swedish climate-change activist Greta Thunberg addressing the U.N. General Assembly Monday.

Watch her speech in this tweet, which shares ABC News video.

Greta Thunberg at #UNGA: "This is all wrong. I shouldn’t be up here. I should be in school on the other side of the ocean. Yet you come to us young people for hope. How dare you. You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words."

Via ABC pic.twitter.com/NudonxKNss — Kyle Griffin (@kylegriffin1) September 23, 2019

Thunberg turned up the volume and intensity for her climate-saving plight in front of the global body from widely followed remarks she delivered to U.S. lawmakers just a few days ago.

President Donald Trump, who pulled the U.S. out of the Paris treaty in part because he says compliance is uneven, made a brief appearance at Monday’s UN climate session — some news agencies pegged the president’s listening-in participation at about 14 minutes.

Don’t miss: Amazon.com has ‘ambitious but achievable’ plan to hit Paris climate goals 10 years early

As of Monday’s session, 66 countries have promised to have more ambitious climate goals and 30 swore to be carbon neutral by midcentury, said Chilean President Sebastian Pinera Echenique, who is hosting the next climate negotiations later this year, according to the Associated Press.

More Key Words: Climate fight must be ‘sexy, fun and cool,’ says young minister for coal-dependent Japan

Thunberg, also a face of so-called flight shaming, which draws attention mostly to the carbon footprint of celebrities on frequent flights and especially private flights, sailed the Atlantic earlier this month from Europe to her U.S. congressional and UN appearances.

Her solo protest in front of Swedish parliament roughly a year ago swelled into last Friday’s global march, believed to be the largest such climate demonstration to date.

description: Teenage Swedish climate-change activist Greta Thunberg urges the U.N. General Assembly to move quickly, share the burden that young people feel.
